image.altText: An older man with greying light hair and glasses wearing a suit and tie stands in front of a blue Reserve Bank of Australia wall

items.synopsis: The RBA delivers relief to mortgage borrowers by deciding to leave rates on hold at 4.1 per cent at its July meeting, after two dozen protesters gather outside its headquarters in Sydney. Follow live.

title.children: RBA pauses interest rate rises 'to assess the state of the economy'

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A lot of you in the comments are telling us that you're doing it tough at the moment and are worried about what the future holds for you, knowing the RBA has flagged future rate rises. If you're experiencing financial distress, there are a number of support services available for you to access. National Debt Helpline : 1800 007 007 Mob Strong Debt Help : 1800 808 488 ASIC's Moneysmart website Australian Financial Complaints Authority Find a financial counsellor Lifeline : 13 11 14 Beyond Blue : 1300 224 636 (This is general information only, and if you require financial advice, please seek out a professional.)
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: If you're struggling to cope with rising interest rates, help is available

children.content: A lot of you in the comments are telling us that you're doing it tough at the moment and are worried about what the future holds for you, knowing the RBA has flagged future rate rises.
If you're experiencing financial distress, there are a number of support services available for you to access.
National Debt Helpline
Mob Strong Debt Help
ASIC's Moneysmart website
Australian Financial Complaints Authority
Find a financial counsellor
Lifeline
Beyond Blue
(This is general information only, and if you require financial advice, please seek out a professional.)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: That's according to research director at RateCity, Sally Tindall, who was speaking about the interest rate decision on the ABC's News Channel before. She says while borrowers will be breathing a sigh of relief now, they're not out of the woods yet. "Really, they [borrowers] should still  expect further rate hikes to come," she said. "Inflation, especially when you look at core inflation, still way too  high. "There is a long way for the  RBA to get that back to the target band of 2%-3%. "While we have a  breather for one month, this will  just give households time to catch up on their monthly repayments. "There is a two-three month lag for when the cash rate goes up and your  monthly repayments go up. "A one month reprieve might not be enough for  many households."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rate pause welcome now, but 'one month reprieve might not be enough'

children.content: That's according to research director at RateCity, Sally Tindall, who was speaking about the interest rate decision on the ABC's News Channel before.
She says while borrowers will be breathing a sigh of relief now, they're not out of the woods yet.

"Inflation, especially when you look at core inflation, still way too  high.
"There is a long way for the  RBA to get that back to the target band of 2%-3%.
"While we have a  breather for one month,
this will  just give households time to catch up on their monthly repayments
"There is a
two-three month lag for when the cash rate goes up and your  monthly repayments go up
"A one month reprieve might not be enough for  many households."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Looking solely at the data, it seems that rising interest rates are having an impact on inflation (which is measured as the consumer price index, or CPI for short). Of course, lifting rates comes with consequences, with mortgage borrowers and small business owners just some of those feeling the pinch. But looking at this graph in isolation, it certainly appears that rising interest rates are working to curb inflation in the economy. That said, the RBA takes in far more indicators into account than just the relationship of inflation and interest rates. (One other thing to note in this graph — the latest monthly inflation data is for May this year, so the cash rate figure is capped at the May rate of 3.85% for purposes of showing the trend.)
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Lifting interest rates is meant to bring down inflation. Is it working?

children.content: Looking solely at the data, it seems that rising interest rates are having an impact on inflation (which is measured as the consumer price index, or CPI for short).
Of course, lifting rates comes with consequences, with mortgage borrowers and small business owners just some of those feeling the pinch.
But looking at this graph in isolation, it certainly appears that rising interest rates are working to curb inflation in the economy.
That said, the RBA takes in far more indicators into account than just the relationship of inflation and interest rates.
(One other thing to note in this graph — the latest monthly inflation data is for May this year, so the cash rate figure is capped at the May rate of 3.85% for purposes of showing the trend.)

image.altText: An image of the Reserve bank sign in Martin Place, Sydney

items.synopsis: The Reserve Bank says rates will remain on hold for July at 4.1 per cent, but more rate hikes could be coming.

title.children: Reserve Bank delivers a reprieve for mortgage holders, but more hikes could be coming

image.altText: Katherine Goodall lays in a hospital bed while giving a thumbs up

items.synopsis: A young mum has qualified as a surgeon despite a shock bowel cancer diagnosis part way through her training.

title.children: Young surgeon's shock bowel discovery highlights growing under 50s cancer risk

image.altText: Heather Anderson portrait

items.synopsis: Adelaide premiership player Heather Anderson is the first known professional female athlete to be diagnosed with the degenerative brain disease chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE).

title.children: 'Highly significant': First professional female athlete diagnosed with CTE in landmark case

image.altText: An elderly woman with glasses smiling with a flower border. An elderly man with glasses smiling.

items.synopsis: A woman related to a 94-year-old woman and her husband, who died in hospital a year apart, has now been charged with two counts of murder after she was arrested earlier today, SA police say.

title.children: Female relative charged with murders of couple, both 94, who died a year apart

image.altText: A male wearing a surgical mask walks past a metal fence holding the straps of his backpack

items.synopsis: A court hears former lawyer Dev Manon "was not motivated by greed" but was a key figure in the scheme to defraud the ATO of $105 million.

title.children: Corrupt lawyer jailed for 14 years over $105m Plutus Payroll tax fraud

image.altText: Anthony Albanese and Rishi Sunak sit at a table

items.synopsis: The furore continues over Jonny Bairstow's controversial dismissal at Lord's, with Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese publicly supporting the tourists amid ongoing debate and rising tensions in the world-famous series.

title.children: Anthony Albanese fires back at British PM over Ashes dismissal furore, defending 'winning' Australians

image.altText: A composite photo of Dr Karishma Dahia on the left and Laura Vissaritis on the right

items.synopsis: Join dog behaviourist Laura Vissaritis and vet Dr Karishma Dahia as they tackle some of your curly canine questions in our live Q&A.

title.children: Is your dog postie-obsessed or an excessive barker? Join our experts as they troubleshoot your canine challenges

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Kara: If a 6 yo rescue dog is other dog reactive (excessively), can they ever be re-socialised to be around other dogs? If so, how can we start this? Thanks for the question Kara! Lovely to hear so many of your rescue dog stories. Here's Laura V 's advice: Laura V: 'Socialisation' is an interesting word. We often want our dogs to be happy to greet other dogs, but what do our dogs want? Dogs who are fearful or anxious want the threat to go away, so ultimately we need to reframe what other dogs mean. This is really complicated because there are so many things contributing to a reactive dog's behaviour - some of which are out of our control. I'd suggest engaging a behaviourist to help work out what the triggers are and what the causes are. Then you can work on managing your environment so your dog doesn't get stressed out. This is a long work in progress, but when you see your dog start to relax and trust you, it is well worth it. Try to set your dog up for success, and avoid letting your dog get past their comfort zone. This means a lot of u-turns, crossing roads and up driveways if you do decide to continue walking him on the streets. That can be very stressful for you both, so chat with your vet and then get some gentle guidance in person from a behaviourist.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Can rescue dogs be socialised?

This means a lot of u-turns, crossing roads and up driveways if you do decide to continue walking him on the streets. That can be very stressful for you both, so chat with your vet and then get some gentle guidance in person from a behaviourist.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Lawrence : Our dogs are old and arthritic (12yo), hence we only walk them around the block, but one stops halfway and we almost have to drag her home. They need to walk to keep fitness and joint movement, but we don't want to force them. What should we do? Dr Karishma 's advice: Osteoarthritis is such a common ailment affecting many of our senior pets. Whilst it is true that we should still provide gentle exercise and enrichment to our geriatric pets, it is important not to over-do it or push them beyond their limits as this can hinder them more than help them. If you find that your dog's can only walk halfway around the block, then reduce their walks to this distance. This is their way of telling you that they are not physically capable of walking further than this without being in discomfort or pain. And as they continue to age, you will likely find that the length of these walks will reduce even further. A good alternative to walking outside if they are having trouble is spending more time in the garden with them so they still get the interaction and fresh air without pushing themselves. Another good alternative is swimming or hydrotherapy for our senior pets who enjoy the water, to keep their joints moving - although this is not for everyone! And finally getting them checked out at the vet is a great idea to get them on an osteoarthritis management plan and provide pain relief where needed. And if they are not at the stage of needing pain management, there are some fantastic natural injections and oral supplements these days that can greatly improve their quality of life and get them moving more freely again.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: How do you help keep old dogs fit and healthy?

children.content: Lawrence

: Our dogs are old and arthritic (12yo), hence we only walk them around the block, but one stops halfway and we almost have to drag her home. They need to walk to keep fitness and joint movement, but we don't want to force them. What should we do?
Dr Karishma
's advice:

Osteoarthritis is such a common ailment affecting many of our senior pets. Whilst it is true that we should still provide gentle exercise and enrichment to our geriatric pets, it is important not to over-do it or push them beyond their limits as this can hinder them more than help
them. If you find that your dog's can only walk halfway around the block, then
reduce their walks

to this distance. This is their way of telling you that they are not physically capable of walking further than this without being in discomfort or pain. And as they continue to age, you will likely find that the length of these walks will reduce even further. A good alternative
to walking outside if they are having trouble is
spending more time in the garden
with them so they still get the interaction and fresh air without pushing themselves.
Another good alternative is
swimming or hydrotherapy
for our senior pets who enjoy the water, to keep their joints moving - although this is not for everyone!
And finally getting them checked out at the vet is a great idea to get them on an osteoarthritis management plan and provide pain relief where needed. And if they are not at the
stage of needing pain management, there are some fantastic natural injections and oral supplements these days that can greatly improve their quality of life and get them moving more freely again.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Stephen: How do we break a habit, a habit that does come and go,      of weeing in the house? Heidi: Why would my rescue dog suddenly wee on my bed right where I sleep? She is well trained, has no notable history of abuse and has been a delight to welcome into our home. Thanks Stephen and Heidi for you questions! I've put this to both Dr Karishma and Laura V. Dr Karishma: Breaking habits, especially ones that are intermittent can be a challenging and lengthy process. The first step is trying to identify the trigger for this behaviour. Some common reasons include territorial spraying if they are not desexed, from urinary incontinence, old age, osteoarthritis, dementia, stress/fear/anxiety - even to noise outside, kidney disease, diabetes, cushing's disease, or urinary tract infections/stones in the bladder. It's important to get your pet checked at the vet to identify any of these underlying issues. Once a trigger has been identified, it usually will make things easier to treat, especially if there is an underlying medical issue. If these things have been ruled out, then re-training your dog may include things like increasing toilet breaks - especially after sleep and rewarding them for peeing in appropriate places. As well as ensuring area's where they have previously urinated are thoroughly cleaned with an enzymatic cleaner that eliminates the smell so they can't recognoise that smell.And considering pheromone collars and diffuser's in the house to help they feel comfortable in their environment if they are an anxious dog. And here's Laura V's take: Laura V: Dogs will wee inside the house for a number of reasons - they have not been trained properly to go outdoors, or they have an underlying anxiety, or they have an underlying medical problem. If it is occasional, try to identify the pattern. If you can predict it, then you can prevent it, by calling your dog outside to the toilet. Putting your dog on a lead can also help as you can manage their behaviour more consistently, preventing them from sneaking away to wee in another room. There is always the possibility that your dog has an underlying infection or disease that needs to be addressed by your vet, so a check up is well worth it. Punishing dogs for having accidents inside only makes them more anxious and can make them more likely to sneak away in another room when you're not looking.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: How do we break the habit of weeing in the house?

in the house to help they feel comfortable in their environment if they are an anxious dog.

image.altText: The outside of the Royal Children's Hospital in Melbourne.

items.synopsis: A coroner finds there was "no clinical indication" two-year-old Callie Griffiths-I'Anson was unsuitable for discharge, despite her death from a surgical complication the next morning.

title.children: Toddler's release from hospital before death was reasonable, coroner finds

image.altText: A soldier waves a Ukrainian flag with his right hand as he holds a rifle in his left hand while standing atop a concrete block.

items.synopsis: While many fret about the "slowness" of the Ukrainian campaign, all military operations consist of pulses and pauses and there is much we do not see in this war. It is important to remain patient, writes Mick Ryan.

title.children: Ukraine's war campaign may seem 'slow', but its strategy is full of surprises — and Russia could be in trouble

image.altText: A dog being assessed at the vet, close up of dog's face

items.synopsis: As people shy away from professional help due to tightening household budgets, vets are seeing the all-too-real consequences for suffering pets.

title.children: Pet owners warned against 'playing vet' amid cost-of-living crisis

image.altText: A man wearing a black jacket, plaid shirt and black beanie holds an acoustic guitar.

items.synopsis: What started off as a casually recorded folk song became a foundational entry in the Australian songbook.

title.children: It began with some chords strummed around a camp fire before becoming an Australian music legacy

image.altText: RBA governor Philip Lowe speaks at the Morgan Stanley Australia summit in Sydney

items.synopsis: With the economy slowing, inflation pressures easing and household expenditure diving, starting the new financial year with hike number 13 could well prove to be an ominous sign, writes Ian Verrender.

title.children: Abandon all logic — whether the RBA pauses rates comes down to a coin toss

image.altText: Police tape across a fence and gate.

items.synopsis: A pet dog was killed in an alleged home invasion in Forest Lake, after three men allegedly tried to coax the residents of the home outside by taking the dog hostage.

title.children: Alleged Brisbane home invaders stabbed pet dog in bid to coax residents outside, police say

image.altText: Bouquets bunch of flowers on the ground.

items.synopsis: A committee set up to distribute the funds says $475,000 has been already transferred to the survivors and family members of the deceased, with more on the way.

title.children: Donations to Hunter Valley bus crash victims tops $1 million, with more fundraisers planned

image.altText: A black-and-white image of a circus performer with a modern-day image of a man in Toreador costume.

items.synopsis: Almost a century after the "greatest tightwire artist of all time" built his career on hiding his Indigenous heritage, Con Colleano's legacy is celebrated through a special tribute in his home town.

title.children: He fooled Hitler and Mussolini, now Lismore celebrates local highwire hero Con Colleano

image.altText: A missing person poster of a Hispanic teenage boy, showing his name and a table with descriptive information.

items.synopsis: Police say Rudy Farias was discovered unconscious outside a church in Houston, Texas, eight years after he went missing.

title.children: Teen who vanished while walking dogs in 2015 found unconscious outside Texas church

image.altText: A photo of a car being driven at night with a blurry night trail.

items.synopsis: Victoria's road toll is at a 12-year high. A driver, who spent time in jail after he killed another person while speeding, shares his story in the hope others don't make a similar mistake.

title.children: 'Anthony' made an impulsive decision to speed and it cost another driver their life

image.altText: A person takes a photo as a full moon known as the "Buck Moon" rises behind the Temple of Poseidon, in Cape Sounion, near Athens

items.synopsis: Don't stress if the cloudy weather locked you out of last night's supermoon — there's three more before the end of the year.

title.children: Clouds blocked the buck supermoon for many in Australia, so here are photos of it from around the world

image.altText: A composite image of two men of Chinese appearance.

items.synopsis: Two men living in Australia have criticised a move by Hong Kong authorities to issue them with arrest warrants under a controversial national security law, putting a $HK1 million bounty on their heads.

title.children: Adelaide man says warrant for his arrest in Hong Kong shows China is 'more a threat than a friend to the world'

image.altText: The burnt remains of a 4WD vehicle, in darkness.

items.synopsis: Crime scenes have been established to identify skeletal remains discovered in separate cars overnight.

title.children: Two bodies found in separate burnt-out cars in Sydney, as crime scenes set up

image.altText: A composite image of Novak Djokovic and Jordan Thompson

items.synopsis: Jordan Thompson produces a comeback win for the ages at Wimbledon, with his reward a shot at defending champion Novak Djokovic.

title.children: Aussie's Wimbledon epic gets him showdown with Djokovic

image.altText: A graphic of a man's outline, in red, threatening a woman's outline, in blue

items.synopsis: A woman shares her story of experiencing escalating coercive control as the South Australian government commits to criminalising the form of domestic abuse by the end of the year.

title.children: From shared bank accounts to coercive control, woman shares story of domestic abuse as SA minister introduces bill

image.altText: Aircraft sit at the gates of Darwin International Airport.

items.synopsis: Jetstar flights between Darwin and Denpasar have been put on hold, as work by the Australian Defence Department places the plans of Top End travellers in jeopardy.

title.children: Flight sales to Bali are being pulled in northern Australia's hottest months. What's going on?

image.altText: a woman looking at facebook marketplace on a computer

items.synopsis: Ever sold something on Facebook Marketplace or Gumtree? Without knowing it, you might've put yourself in danger. Here's how to stay safe when selling items online.

title.children: Seller beware: How putting up items for sale on Facebook Marketplace and Gumtree could put you at risk

image.altText: A man in a black suit stands next to a woman in a floral print dress

items.synopsis: Leandro's mother and eldest daughter of Robert, Drena, announced the news in an Instagram post on Monday.

title.children: Robert De Niro's grandson, Leandro De Niro Rodriguez, dies at 19

image.altText: A collection of maneki-neko or lucky cat statues.

items.synopsis: Maneki-neko — otherwise known as lucky cats or welcoming cats — are found around the world. But where the ceramic cats began to be sold remains a mystery, writes Tets Kimura.

title.children: They're now found behind cash registers all over the world, but where did the beckoning cat come from?

image.altText: Three Fijian men wearing CFA uniforms.

items.synopsis: Nine Fijian recruits have spent months practising drills and completing assessments with a Victorian brigade. They are now ready to defend their new home from natural disasters.

title.children: 'Proud' day arrives for PALM workers joining firefighter ranks

image.altText: A young man posing with a small snowman on a rock.

items.synopsis: Heavy rainfall and cold temperatures across southern WA has broken records, with one weather station on the south coast topping a 48-year record by nearly 100mm.

title.children: Cold and rainy June weather breaks records across southern WA

image.altText: letter boxes falling over

items.synopsis: Former Dyldam bosses Fayad Fayad and Remon Fayad, and their father Sam Fayad, are behind apartment blocks across Sydney slapped with sanctions from the NSW Building Commissioner.

title.children: Serious defects in Sydney unit blocks linked to family of property developers as owners wait to move in

image.altText: A bearded man in front of a river wearing a wide brim hat slightly smiling at the camera

items.synopsis: Ray Burgess was diagnosed with advanced cancer but didn't receive treatment for months due to long outpatient waitlists and lack of specialised equipment.

title.children: Ray's GP told him he had colon cancer in December. He couldn't begin treatment until May, and by June he was dead

image.altText: the president of indonesia arrives at an airport as he is greeted by officials

items.synopsis: Foreign Minister Penny Wong flags a relaxation of visa rules for some Indonesians, as the country's president arrives in Sydney for bilateral talks.

title.children: Easing of visa rules for Indonesians flagged as president arrives in Sydney

image.altText: group of people sitting around a bushfire

items.synopsis: Big Red Bash organisers say the journey to one of the world's most remote music festivals is all part of the experience, but many travellers got more than they bargained for on the way to this year's event.

title.children: Road closures, muddy chaos for travellers heading to Birdsville's Big Red Bash

image.altText: Expert plane model maker Steve Keddie explains how he builds his spectacular creations

items.synopsis: Steve Keddie spends months painstakingly hand-crafting his pieces. His collection of miniatures reflects the variety of aircraft on display at Shellharbour, in one of Australia's most comprehensive aviation museums.

title.children: Master model-plane maker's made-from-scratch miniatures showcased at aviation museum
